WW1 and WW2 veteran Battleship Texas has been a floating museum for 75 years, and has seen significant hull degradation, growing critical over the last 15 years. Her keepers have finally found funding to get it dry docked and restored, and today was the trip from her berth across Galveston Bay.

From the class of 1912, Id say the HMS Erin (Re≈üadiye) or SMS Kaiser would be more well rounded. 

By the time hostilities started, you have some amazing battlecruisers like the Derflinger and of course the Queen Elizabeths and later the Bayerns. The Texas would not want to test cases with either.

It is great that the US managed to conserve so many of these battlewagons, although we should have also kept a couple of the Pearl Harbor fleet- like the Pennsylvania for instance or even a slightly older design.

The British went the opposite route and converted such legends as the Bismarck smashing Rodney- which mission killed that legendary ship in 15 minutes by popping the A & B turrets like grape- into spoons and canned goods. 

That not one of the venerable Queen Elizabeths (Warspite would be a great choice),  KGVs, Iron Dukes or battlecruisers was saved is criminal. We still have both models of treaty battleship as museums (Alabama/Massachusetts and the North Carolina) plus the Iowas. The Texas is the lone pre-Great War Dreadnought. It discharged both its duty and guns with aplomb.
The Texas cost less than 6 million new.   The more you know.  Today's money has no value.

context: As the last surviving Battleship from WWI, thank God Texans have the will and spirit to remember why we once were a great power, and willing to pay for a fantastic memorial to that great past, so our Texan sons and daughters will know what once made us great.
I see little value for these floating museums to still be on the water.  If there's no chance for them to be reactivated, put 'em on dry land and use the savings for upkeep. Win-win!

replies.context: No ship of this weight was ever designed to be un-supported without water.  If the Texas or any other ship of it's size were put on a dry land mount, it would slowly pancake on top of itself as the decks bowed and collapsed on each other.  You have a thick armor plated belt.  Up to 18 inches of solid steel for the command bridge and tons of armor for the turrets.  There's a YouTube channel called "Battleship New Jersey".  You can learn a ton watching it.
No one's saying 'un-supported'.  Naturally there's going to be an engineering solution needed, but I guarantee you the the savings to offset the project would be realized quickly, if not immediately.
